conclusion: The semi-cylindrical transparent brick has a radius r and a refractive index n. The laser beam starts at point A and moves towards point C along the diameter AC at a uniform speed v.
The laser beam enters the brick at point A and travels along the diameter AC.
As the laser beam moves from A to C, it will refract at the boundary of the semi-cylinder.

When the laser beam reaches the arc surface ABC, it will refract according to Snell's Law: n1 sin θ1 = n2 sin θ2, where n1 is the refractive index of the brick (n), n2 is the refractive index of the surrounding medium (assumed to be air, n2 = 1), θ1 is the angle of incidence, and θ2 is the angle of refraction.
The critical angle θc for total internal reflection is given by: sin θc = 1/n.
If the angle of incidence θ1 is greater than θc, the laser beam will undergo total internal reflection and not emerge from the arc surface.
The laser beam will emerge from the arc surface when the angle of incidence θ1 is less than or equal to θc. This condition is met when the laser beam is at or near the center of the semi-cylinder.
The laser beam travels from A to C at a speed v. The distance AC is the diameter of the semi-cylinder, which is 2r.
The time t taken to travel from A to C is: t = 2r/v.
The laser beam will emerge from the arc surface ABC when it reaches the center of the semi-cylinder, which is at time t = 2r/v.
